revision.text:
'''AICPA Statements of Position''' (SOPs), available full-text at the links below from the [[University of Mississippi]]'s Library Digital Collections with the permission of the [[American Institute of Certified Public Accountants]] (AICPA), have been issued by the AICPA's Accounting Standards Division since 1974 and are meant to influence the development of [[accounting]] standards and to propose revisions to the AICPA's Audit and Accounting Guide (AAGs) series.<ref>''Statements of Position of the Accounting Standards Division as of January 1, 1978.''American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, 1978</ref><ref>''AICPA Technical Practice Aids as of June 1, 2008.'' American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, 2008</ref>
Those SOPs dealing with accounting standards are superseded by the [[Financial Accounting Standards Board|FASB's]] [http://asc.fasb.org Accounting Standards Codification].
Audit and Attest SOPs were issued to revise or supplement the AICPA's Audit and Accounting Guides, provide implementation guidance for specific types of audit and attest engagements, and guidance in specialized areas of audit and attest. These SOPs have the same authority as the AAGs.
The full-text in the list below links to reproductions of SOPs as originally issued. Revisions, deletions, and status changes are recorded in the annual AICPA publication ''Technical Practice Aids'' which began in 1977.

{{advert|date=July 2016}} {{EngvarB|date=April 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Adekunle Ayeni | image = | birth_date = | birth_place = | occupation = Media Practitioner, entrepreneur | nationality = Nigerian | alma_mater = [[University of Ibadan]] | website ={{url|ayenithegreat.ng}} }} '''Adekunle Ayeni''' is a Nigerian public relations practitioner, journalist, trained scientist and businessman. He is the publisher of ''[[Nigerian Entertainment Today]]''. He is also the founder of [[Black House Media]], a Public Relations firm, and [[ID Africa]], a digital marketing agency.<ref>{{cite news |title='Why I chose to be a journalist without formal training' -NET newspaper publisher, Ayeni Adekunle |url=http://encomium.ng/classics-why-i-chose-to-be-a-journalist-without-formal-training-net-newspaper-publisher-ayeni-adekunle/ |date=28 February 2012 |newspaper=Encomium}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=BHM Group Announces The Launch of Pan-African Digital Agency |url=http://connectnigeria.com/articles/2015/03/02/bhm-group-announces-the-launch-of-pan-african-digital-agency/ |date=2 March 2015 |newspaper=Connect Nigeria}}</ref>
==Background== Adekunle Ayeni is from [[Oka-Akoko]] area of [[Ondo State]], had his primary and secondary education (Awori College, Ojo) in [[Lagos]], and his University education at the [[University of Ibadan]], [[Ibadan]], [[Oyo State]] where he studied [[Microbiology]] and got his BSc degree.<ref>{{cite web |title=Who Am I? |url=http://ayenithegreat.ng/who-am-i/}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=From Sciences to Publicity |url=http://www.cre8tiventreps.com/from-sciences-to-publicity/ |author=Adewole Ajao |date=11 August 2014 |newspaper=Cre8tiveEntreps}}</ref>
==Career== Adekunle Ayeni, who is referred to in Nigerian media circle as 'Ayeni the Great',<ref>{{cite web|title=T.I.N MAGAZINE: Ayeni Adekunle Full Biography, Life And Career.{TheNET.ng Founder&CEO}|url=http://www.takemetonaija.com/2016/01/ayeni-adekunle-full-biographylife-and.html|website=www.takemetonaija.com|accessdate=5 May 2016}}</ref> made attempts to act before he opted to manage artistes then in his locality of Okokomaiko in [[Lagos State]]. He also tried organising awards and shows. A trained microbiologist, Ayeni later took up a profession in writing. He has a career path that has taken him across major media houses in [[Nigeria]]. Ayeni has narrated how he embraced writing at a secondary school age. "I started writing in secondary school because I had consumed a lot of literature. My parents had a lot of books around the house. My mum was a consumer of literature…I had read a lot and upon leaving secondary school, I knew I wanted to do literature, entertainment and all that...All though my stay in university I was always writing, so it was natural that I continued when I left.. Eventually, I got a chance to write for Encomium and within a month or two, they gave me the music column to handle."<ref>{{cite news |title='Why I chose to be a journalist without formal training' -NET newspaper publisher, Ayeni Adekunle |url=http://encomium.ng/classics-why-i-chose-to-be-a-journalist-without-formal-training-net-newspaper-publisher-ayeni-adekunle/ |date=28 February 2012 |newspaper=Encomium}}</ref>
==Journalism== Adekunle had a stint as a feature editor with ''[[Hip Hop World Magazine]]''. After graduating from the [[University of Ibadan]], he joined ''Encomium Weekly'' as showbiz columnist, after which he moved to ''[[ThisDay]]''. In July 2008, Adekunle joined ''[[The Punch]]'' as an E-Punch columnist. "Working for Encomium I knew I wasn't going to be there for too long, I had always wanted to do my own stuff, but needed to gain some experience working for others. But because I wanted to also taste the other side of the print media, I joined Thisday newspaper and finally, The Punch. It was after that that I felt it was time for me to start my own newspaper."<ref>{{cite web |title=Thenetng/BHM Founder, 'Ayeni The Great' Speaks To Pulse |url=http://pulse.ng/gist/thenetng-bhm-founder-ayeni-the-great-speaks-to-pulse-com-ng-id2505357.html |date=27 November 2014 |website=Pulse}}</ref>
==Publishing TheNET== Upon leaving ''[[The Punch]]'' newspaper in [[Lagos]], Adekunle Ayeni founded ''[[Nigeria Entertainment Today]]'' (NET), a newspaper and website specially dedicated to reportage of entertainment in [[Nigeria]], which online version was launched on 23 November 2009, and its print newspaper hit the newsstands on 26 April 2010. The "weekly print edition, printed in different locations, and circulated nationally (in over 37 towns/cities across the country)"<ref>{{cite web |title=After 2 years, Adekunle Ayeni, Nigerian Entertainment Today Publisher shares his success story |url=http://olorisupergal.com/after-2-years-adekunle-ayeni-nigerian-entertainment-today-publisher-shares-his-success-story-at-the-creativesessions/ |date=26 April 2012 |website=Olori Supergal}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=About Nigerian Entertainment Today Adekunle |url=http://thenet.ng/about/ |date=28 February 2012 |newspaper=NET}}</ref> The media platform has been organising the annual Nigerian Entertainment Conference, the umbrella conference for the Nigerian entertainment sector, which brings together all stakeholders in the industry to have a full day conversations, workshops, exhibitions and master-classes. The event, which holds in Lagos, Nigeria on Wednesday 22 April 2015, debuted in April 2013 at Eko Hotels & Suites, [[Lagos]].
==Black House Media== Adekunle Ayeni founded [[Black House Media]] in 2006 for public relations services. In 2012, he led a team of software and content developers in [Nigeria] to unveil the BHM App, which is the "first PR mobile application" in Nigeria. The application has been described as "a complete resource centre for the entire media and marketing communications industries especially for the clients seeking information about PR agencies in the country." It took Ayeni and his team one year to develop the BHM App. Ayeni, in an interview he held with Raheem Akingbolu of [[ThisDay]] newspapers, said that the BHM App development was informed by "the crave for best practice. It is high time the Public Relations industry in Nigeria kept the world abreast about its stories and the great things happening in the market. It is our belief that Agencies' database, news hub, social PR, news and tips and workshop videos that would be on this application will help marketing practitioners, including journalists to be more accurate and informed." The application was unveiled at an event graced by industry experts.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ayeni Adekunle's BHM Launches Nigeria's First PR App |url=http://www.sabinews.com/all-news/ayeni-adekunle-bhm-launches-nigerias-first-pr-app/ |author=Editor |date=5 August 2014 |newspaper=SabiNews}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Ayeni: PR is About the Truth Well Told |url=http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/ayeni-pr-is-about-the-truth-well-told/190335/ |author=Raheem Akingbolu |date=2 October 2014 |newspaper=ThisDay |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402123534/http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/ayeni-pr-is-about-the-truth-well-told/190335/ |archivedate=2 April 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Trending Market |url=http://brandsmart.com.ng/news/trending-markets/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20150309095946/http://brandsmart.com.ng/news/trending-markets/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2015-03-09 |newspaper=BrandsMart }}</ref> In February 2015, Ayeni announced the launch of his digital media agency, named ID Africa. "ID Africa aims to fill the gap left by digital marketing firms across Africa who currently offers only the most generic of marketing and digital ad services."<ref>{{cite news |title= BHM Group announces the launch of Pan-African Digital Agency |url= http://encomium.ng/bhm-group-announces-the-launch-of-pan-african-digital-agency/ |date=27 February 2015 |newspaper=Encomiun}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=BHM Group Announces The Launch of Pan-African Digital Agency |url=http://connectnigeria.com/articles/2015/03/02/bhm-group-announces-the-launch-of-pan-african-digital-agency/ |date=2 March 2015 |newspaper=Connect Nigeria}}</ref> Ayeni is a member of the Public Relations Consultants Association of Nigeria (PRCAN), a trade sectoral group founded in 1984 for the public relations industry in Nigeria. Ayeni delivered a paper on Role of digital Public Relations in managing online communities at the 10th edition of a Master Class series organised by the association. Ayeni posited that "there is nothing like Digital PR…What we need to focus on, and talk about is Today's PR and Today's online communities. Today's PR is about story telling, about content. Today's PR is increasingly about using the understanding of the psychology of identified publics to weave our message into their minute-to-minute lives and have them thanking us for it."<ref>{{cite news|title=There is nothing like digital PR –Ayeni Adekunle |url=http://dailyindependentnig.com/2014/03/there-is-nothing-like-digital-pr-ayeni-adekunle/ |author=Goddie Ofose |newspaper=Daily Independent |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402192538/http://dailyindependentnig.com/2014/03/there-is-nothing-like-digital-pr-ayeni-adekunle/ |archivedate=2 April 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Ayeni Adekunle Expound The Principles of Public Relations at PRCAN Master Class |url=http://olorisupergal.com/ayeni-adekunle-expound-the-principles-of-public-relations-at-prcan-master-class/ |date=13 March 2014 |website=Olori Supergal}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}

[[Greenville, Delaware|Greenville]], [[Delaware]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1856|10|4|1798|4|11|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Greenville, Delaware|Greenville]], [[Delaware]] | office = | salary = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | parents= [[Éleuthère Irénée du Pont]], Sophie Madeleine Dalmas du Pont | religion = | spouse = Margaretta Elizabeth La Motte | children = Victorine Elizabeth du Pont

[[Lammot du Pont]]
Alfred Victor du Pont
Mary Sophie du Pont
Antoine Biderman du Pont | website = | footnotes = }} '''Alfred Victor Philadelphe du Pont de Nemours''' (April 11, 1798 – October 4, 1856) was [[French American]] [[chemist]] and [[industrialist]], who was the eldest son and successor of [[Éleuthère Irénée du Pont]], the founder of the [[DuPont|E.I. du Pont de Nemours and Company]]. ==Early life and family== {{main|Du Pont family}} Du Pont was born in [[Paris]], son of [[Éleuthère Irénée du Pont]] and Sophie Madeleine Dalmas du Pont. He came to the United States in 1800 as an infant and grew up around the gunpowder mills founded by his father on the [[Brandywine Creek (Christina River)|Brandywine Creek]] in [[Delaware]]. Later he attended Mount Airy College, in [[Germantown, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Germantown]], [[Pennsylvania]] and then studied chemistry at [[Dickinson College]]. While there he was president of ''Belles Lettres Literary Society'' and became a friend of one of his professors, [[Thomas Cooper (US politician)|Thomas Cooper]]. He later became Cooper's assistant at the [[University of Pennsylvania]]. Du Pont married American Margaretta Elizabeth "Molly" La Motte (or Lammot) in 1824; they had seven children. ==E.I. du Pont Company== In 1818, du Pont returned home to help his father rebuild the gunpowder company after a disastrous explosion that killed 33 people and injured his mother. He worked closely with the men in the mills and was particularly interested in researching new gunpowder chemical developments. The laboratory was his home. However, after spending nearly 20 years as a "powderman," and after a reorganization of the partnership by James Antoine Bidermann, he became head of the company in 1837. It was a difficult role for him, and after leading the company through a recovery from a disastrous mill explosion in 1847, he retired in poor health in 1850. ==Death and legacy== Alfred du Pont died October 4, 1856 at Eleutherian Mills, near [[Greenville, Delaware|Greenville]], [[Delaware]], and is buried in the du Pont de Nemours Cemetery near Greenville. His son, Alfred Victor du Pont, would become a founding father of [[Phi Kappa Sigma]] in 1850. ==See also== *[[Du Pont family]] for other family members and relationships *[[Hagley Museum and Library]] ==References== *{{cite book | author=du Pont, Pierre S. | title=Genealogy of the du Pont Family 1739-1942| location=Wilmington | publisher=Hambleton Printing & Publishing| year=1942 | id= }} *{{cite book | author=Dutton, William S. | title=Du Pont, One Hundred and Forty Years | location=New York | publisher=Charles Scribner's Sons | year=1942 | id= }} ==External links== {{Commons category|Alfred V. du Pont}} * [http://www2.dupont.com/Phoenix_Heritage/en_US/1837_detail.html DuPont profile] * [http://archives.dickinson.edu/people/alfred-victor-du-pont-1798-1856 Dickinson College profile] {{DuPont}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Du Pont, Alfred V.}} [[Category:1798 births|Dupont, Alfred Victor]] [[Category:1856 deaths|Dupont, Alfred Victor]] [[Category:American businesspeople|Dupont, Alfred Victor]] [[Category:Dickinson College alumni|Dupont, Alfred]] [[Category:People from Greenville, Delaware|Dupont, Alfred Victor]] [[Category:People from Paris|Dupont, Alfred]] [[Category:Du Pont family|Alfred Victor Philadelphe]] [[Category:French emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Burials at Du Pont de Nemours Cemetery|Alfred V. du Pont]]

Vladimir Verbitskiy ([[CEO]]){{Cite news|url=https://www.leaprate.com/forex/executives/vladimir-verbitskiy-named-ceo-of-the-alpari-brand/|title=Vladimir Verbitskiy named CEO of the Alpari brand|date=2018-05-08|work=LeapRate|access-date=2018-05-08|first=Valentina|last=Kirilova}} | hq_location = [[Port Louis]], [[Mauritius]] | key_people = | industry = [[Financial services]] | services = [[Financial market|Financial Brokerage]] | homepage = hide }} '''Alpari Group''' is a [[binary option]]s, [[Foreign exchange market|foreign exchange]], precious metals, and [[Contract for difference|CFD]] broker that has a record of insolvency and regulatory difficulties. The company's UK entity entered [[insolvency]] on January 19, 2015, following heavy losses trading the [[Swiss franc]] against the [[euro]].{{cite web|title=News for customers of Alpari (UK) Limited|url=https://www.fca.org.uk/news/statements/news-customers-alpari-uk-limited|publisher=[[Financial Conduct Authority]]|accessdate=March 6, 2017|date=January 20, 2015}} In April 2015, the company's US [[National Futures Association|NFA]] membership was revoked, preventing them from offering their services in the United States.{{cite web |url=http://www.nfa.futures.org/basicnet/Details.aspx?entityid=ISBX1mhBYJ0%3d&rn=N |title= ALPARI US LLC |publisher=NFA |access-date=14 April 2015}} The company is licensed to trade in *[[Belarus]]{{cite web|title=Information about the legal entities included in the forex companies registry as of 03.09.2017|url=http://www.nbrb.by/finsector/forex/register|website=National Bank of the Republic of Belarus|accessdate=March 9, 2017}} *[[Belize]]{{cite web|title=List F|url=http://www.ifsc.gov.bz/licensed-service-providers/list-f/|website=International Financial Services Commission of Belize|accessdate=March 9, 2017}} *[[Mauritius]]{{cite web|title=Public Register|url=https://publicregister.fscmauritius.org/PublicRegister/MASTActionServlet?do=FormEdit&id=ViewFormPR.xml&key_1=C113012295&key_2=SEC21B&key_3=&key_count=3|website=Financial Services Commission, Mauritius|accessdate=March 9, 2017}} *[[Russia]]{{cite web|title=О выдаче лицензии ООО “Альпари Форекс”|url=http://www.cbr.ru/publ/vestnik/vestnik/ves161207106.pdf|website=ВЕСТНИК БАНКА РОССИИ|publisher=Central Bank of Russia|accessdate=March 9, 2017|page=10 |date= December 7, 2016}}{{Request quotation|date=March 2017}} The company's charter is registered in [[Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]]. Alpari Research & Analysis Limited, which gives a London address, provides only research and analysis and is not licensed to trade.{{cite web|title=The brand Alpari|url=https://www.alpari.by/our_brand/|website=Alpari (Belarus)|accessdate=March 9, 2017}} Andrey Valerievich Dashin claims ownership of both Alpari and another foreign exchange broker FXTM also known as ForexTime.{{cite web|title=Andry Valerievich Dashin|url=http://www.dashin.ru/en/business/65-business|publisher=Andry Valerievich Dashin|accessdate=March 9, 2017}} ==History== The company was established in [[Kazan]], [[Russia]], in 1998 by Daniel Skowronski, who became the first CEO, and Andrey Vedikhin, Andrey Dashin and Gleb Petrov.{{citation needed|date=April 2015}} ===United Kingdom=== Alpari (UK) was founded in 2004. It was regulated by the [[Financial Conduct Authority]] in September 2006. The company opened and closed several branches in other countries. Cyprus office opened in 2010 and the [[CySEC]] license was acquired that year and renounced in December 2012. That office closed in February 2013.{{cite web |url=http://www.cyprus.com/alpari-financial-services-success-story.html |title=Alpari Financial Services Success Story |website=Cyprus.com |access-date=13 April 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://www.cysec.gov.cy/CMSPages/GetFile.aspx?guid=cb17ffcf-09da-44ba-8419-14e436c7be0f |title=CySEC Announcement |date=8 May 2013 |publisher=[[CySEC]] |access-date=13 April 2015}} Alpari (UK) entered Indian market in 2008 and left India in March 2014.{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/business/Industry/alpari-india-shuts-shop/article5845126.ece |title=Alpari India shuts shop |last1=Mishra |first1=Lalatendu |date=28 March 2014 |website=TheHindu.com |access-date=13 April 2015}} For UK residents, the company also offered financial spread betting on Forex and indices. On January 16, 2015, Alpari has entered insolvency following heavy losses the previous day when the [[Swiss National Bank]] removed the [[Swiss franc|franc]]'s ceiling against the [[euro]].{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/currency/11349958/Swiss-franc-shock-forces-West-Ham-shirt-sponsor-Alpari-out-of-business.html |title=Swiss franc shock forces West Ham shirt sponsor Alpari out of business |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|date=16 January 2015 |accessdate=13 April 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-30846543 |title=Alpari UK currency broker folds over Swiss franc turmoil |publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=16 January 2015 |accessdate=13 April 2015}} On January 19, Alpari (UK) Ltd. applied for formal insolvency and the [[High Court of Justice|English High Court]] appointed a special administrators from [[KPMG]] under Special Administration Regime.{{cite web|url=https://www.insolvency-kpmg.co.uk/Viewer/pdfViewer.aspx?sid=leyybbwkvh2gkiypbfyiy4qf&did=5ff16c46-7296-41aa-9335-b4bdb198c788| title=Notice of special administrators' appointment|date=19 January 2015 |accessdate=13 April 2015}} ===Russia=== Alpari-Broker Ltd. ({{lang-rus|ООО «Альпари-Брокер»}}) was established as legal entity in September 2008 in Kazan, Russia. It is licensed as a professional participant of the equity markets for providing brokerage, dealership and money managing services by the [[Central Bank of Russia]]{{cite web |url=http://www.cbr.ru/sbrfr/archive/fsfr/ffms/ru/contributors/financialmarket/market_professional_operators/brokers/list_brokers/list_brokers3/index.html |language=ru |title=Список организаций, имеющих лицензию профессионального участника рынка ценных бумаг на осуществление брокерской деятельности |date=17 January 2014 |website=CBR.ru |access-date=13 April 2015}} {{Request quotation|date=March 2017}} Additionally, it is an associated member of NAFD (National Association of Forex Dealers), a [[self-regulatory organization]] created by Forex brokers.{{cite web|url=http://nafd.ru/en/reestr-chlenov/ |title=Members of NAFD |website=NAFD.ru |access-date=23 March 2016}} Sergey Vyazmin, the director of international development at Alpari, is also on the board of directors of this SRO.{{cite web|url=http://nafd.ru/en/sovet-directorov/ |title=Board of directors |website=NAFD.ru |access-date=23 March 2017}} Since March 2017, Alpari is a member of AFD (Association of Forex Dealers) — the only SRO accredited by the Russian central bank.{{cite web|url=http://www.brokersearch.ru/en/news/alpari-member-association-forex-dealers.html |title="Alpari Forex" became a member of the Association of Forex dealers |website=BrokerSearch.ru |date=14 March 2017 |access-date=23 March 2017}} According to the Finmarket information agency, in 2014, Alpari became a top Russian Forex dealer, based on the number of clients and average monthly turnover. The company has 120,000 active clients or a 28.35% market share. The second-largest company is Forex Club, with its 7,183 clients and a 16.97% market share.{{cite journal |author=K.S. Myrzin, T.G. Ilyina |title=Statistics of Private Forex Trading in Russia and the USA |url=http://journals.tsu.ru/uploads/import/1323/files/1(17)_039.pdf |accessdate=2016-09-25 |journal=Accounting and Finance |pages=39–42 |volume=1 |issue=17 |year=2015 }} ===United States=== Alpari US LLC was established in 2006.{{cite web|title=Company Overview of Alpari (US), LLC |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=225062898 |accessdate=3 July 2017|publisher=Bloomberg}} It had its [[National Futures Association|NFA]] membership approved in November 2007 and removed in April 2015. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} [[Category:Financial services companies based in London]] [[Category:Financial services companies of Russia]] [[Category:Companies based in Mauritius]] [[Category:Companies based in Dubai]] [[Category:Foreign exchange companies]] [[Category:Financial derivative trading companies]] [[Category:Online brokerages]] [[Category:Defunct companies]]

{{Infobox person | name = Bill Huang | native_name = {{lang|zh-Hans-CN|黄晓庆}} | birth_name = | other_names = | death_date = <!-- {{death date and age|}} --> | death_place = | death_cause = | nationality = | ancestor = | ethnicity = | education = [[Huazhong University of Science & Technology]], [[University of Illinois]] | occupation = [[serial entrepreneur]] | agent = | known_for = [[CloudMinds]] | notable_works = | television = | party = | movement = | religion = | relatives = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = }} '''Bill Huang''' ({{zh|c=黄晓庆|p=Huáng Xiǎoqìng}}) is a Chinese [[serial entrepreneur]].<ref>{{cite news|title=助力學子科學夢想 ——“千人計劃”專家走進電子科大|url=http://news.takungpao.com.hk/mainland/topnews/2016-12/3407542.html|accessdate=31 August 2017|agency=大公報}}</ref> He was the leader in [[China Mobile]] Research Institution in 2007.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/info/2017-06/03/c_136336591.htm|title=新华网|accessdate=31 August 2017|work=news.xinhuanet.com}}</ref> In 2015, Huang founded [[CloudMinds]] Inc., the first cloud-based intelligent robot technology and operating company in the world.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cloudminds.com/details/rJeusTjVl.html|title=达闼 中国官方网站|accessdate=31 August 2017|work=www.cloudminds.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/info/2017-06/03/c_136336591.htm|title=开启手机“硬件开放”时代的梦想家-新华网|accessdate=31 August 2017|work=news.xinhuanet.com}}</ref>
== Life and career == Bill Huang graduated from [[Huazhong University of Science & Technology]] with a bachelor's degree in Electrical Engineering. After 2 years studying at the [[University of Illinois]], he received master's degree in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science.<ref>{{cite web|title=黄晓庆 - 中国留学人员广州科技交流会|url=https://www.ocs-gz.gov.cn/news/detail/4761|website=www.ocs-gz.gov.cn|accessdate=31 August 2017}}</ref>
Huang entered [[Bell Laboratories]] to work on researches in Asynchronous Transfer Mode in 1990. In 1994, he joined Unitech Telecom and became the co-founder of [[UTStarcom|UTStarcom Holdings Corp.]] a year later. After that, Huang developed the [[operating system]] WACOS.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://mall.cnki.net/magazine/Article/DXJS200604038.htm|title=让数字电视随心看——访UT斯达康高级副总裁兼首席技术官黄晓庆-《电信技术》2006年04期-中国知网|accessdate=31 August 2017|work=mall.cnki.net}}</ref>
In 1996, Huang put forward the "Network is the Switch" soft switch concept. That same year, he co-established the International Soft switch Consortium (ISC) and developed the first mobile soft switch system in the world and the first carrier-class streaming media exchange and IPTV system.<ref name="labs">{{Cite web|url=http://labs.chinamobile.com/members/info_7|title=中国移动研究院|accessdate=31 August 2017|work=labs.chinamobile.com}}</ref>
With the aim to build a research and development center like Bell Labs, Huang joined [[China Mobile]] in 2007. He was the leader in China Mobile Research Institution, and later proposed the concept of constructing the three infrastructures (network, applications and terminals) of the next-generation mobile internet for the carriers. Besides, he built China Mobile "Big Cloud" cloud computing platform. The platform carried out development of cloud computing and big data platform, supporting the world's largest operator of public and private clouds construction and services.<ref name="labs"/>
In 2012, Huang created a new architecture for building intelligent robotics system, the cloud-based robot system. It contains the idea to split the robot into three parts, cloud, mobile network and terminal, which forms complete servicing robots that can assist companies and families. <ref>{{cite web|title=30载通信老将 要做IOT时代运营商 软银富士康加盟|url=http://www.sohu.com/a/126873293_115978|website=www.sohu.com|accessdate=31 August 2017|date=21 February 2017}}</ref>
In 2015, Huang founded [[CloudMinds]] Inc., the first cloud-based [[intelligent robot]] technology and operating company in the world.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cloudminds.com/details/rJeusTjVl.html|title=达闼 中国官方网站|accessdate=31 August 2017|work=www.cloudminds.com|language=en}}</ref>
== Achievements == Bill Huang has received many awards throughout his career. He was selected as ''Talent 1000'' (千人计划) Plan Experts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://1000plan.org/qrjh/article/598|title=黄晓庆_千人计划_千人计划_千人计划网|accessdate=31 August 2017|work=1000plan.org}}</ref> In 2007, he was listed on 100 Most Influential Persons in the Chinese Mobility Industry.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://tech.qq.com/a/20080123/000296_3.htm?client=tim&ptlang=2052&source&ADUIN=909610154&ADSESSION=1498107229&ADTAG=CLIENT.QQ.5525_.0&ADPUBNO=26689|title=2007中国手机业最有影响力100人颁奖典礼_科技_腾讯网|accessdate=31 August 2017|work=tech.qq.com}}</ref>Huang received "Eleventh Five-Year" National Science and Technology Award for Outstanding Contributions on Implementation in 2011.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.most.gov.cn/tztg/201102/W020110217614623128085.pdf|title=中华人民共和国“十一五”国家科技计划执行突出贡献奖|accessdate=2017-06-25|author=|date=|publisher=}}</ref>In 2016, he received IEEE CQR Chairman's Award, which was the first time that a Chinese CEO to achieve so.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://tech.xinmin.cn/2016/05/13/30011951.html|title=首位中国企业技术领袖获IEEE CQR主席大奖_科技_新民网|accessdate=31 August 2017|work=tech.xinmin.cn}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.1000plan.org/lianyihui2/news/405|title=“千人计划”专家联谊会|accessdate=31 August 2017|work=www.1000plan.org}}</ref>
== References == <references />

{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2017}} {{infobox person | name = Calvin H. Gurley | image = CalvinGurleyFire.png | image_size = 200px | alt = Photo of Calvin H. Gurley | birth_date = {{circa}} 1954<ref name= anacostia/> | occupation = [[Accountant]]<ref>Brisbane, Arthur S.; Walsh, Elsa. "Clarke Rules Out Challenging Barry: D.C. Council Chairman to Seek Reelection". ''The Washington Post''. April 21, 1986. p. D1.</ref> | residence = [[Takoma, Washington, D.C.|Takoma]], [[Washington, D.C.]]<ref name= meet>"[https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/mike-debonis/wp/2014/10/24/meet-an-at-large-d-c-council-candidate-calvin-h-gurley/ Meet an at-large D.C. Council candidate: Calvin H. Gurley]". ''The Washington Post''. October 24, 2014.</ref> | alma_mater = [[Bowie State University]]<ref name= meet/> <sub>[[Bachelor of Science|B.S.]]</sub> | children = 2<ref name= meet/> | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] <sub>(until 2014, since 2015)</sub> [[Independent politician|Independent]] <sub>(2014−2015)</sub> }} '''Calvin H. Gurley''' is an [[accountant]] and [[perennial candidate]]<ref>Sommer, Will. "[http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/news/loose-lips/blog/13134825/meet-the-many-many-d-c-council-at-large-candidates Meet the Many, Many D.C. Council At-Large Candidates]". ''Washington City Paper''. September 3, 2014.</ref><ref name= top/><ref name= looming>Sommer, Will. "[http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/news/loose-lips/blog/13134935/with-election-looming-pitts-leads-at-large-race-in-cash-reserves With Election Looming, Pitts Leads At-Large Race in Cash Reserves]". ''Washington City Paper''. October 15, 2014.</ref> living in [[Washington, D.C.]]
==Early years== Gurley was raised in Washington, D.C.<ref name= allmet>DuPree, David. "All-Met Leads Thorobreds". ''The Washington Post''. November 2, 1972. p. D3.</ref> Gurley attended [[Eastern High School (Washington, D.C.)|Eastern High School]], where he played [[defensive back]] on the football team.<ref name= allmet/> Gurley graduated from [[Bowie State University]] with a [[bachelor of science]] degree.<ref name= meet/> Gurley also took graduate classes in finance at the [[University of the District of Columbia]].<ref name= meet/>
From March 1985 to September 1985, Gurley worked as a tax auditor for the District of Columbia Department of Finance and Revenue.<ref name= anacostia>Evans, Sandra. "Anacostia Resident Announces Candidacy for District Mayor".''The Washington Post''. April 6, 1986. p. B5.</ref>
==Political campaigns== ===1986 campaign for Mayor=== Gurley announced his candidacy for [[mayor of the District of Columbia]] in 1986.<ref name= anacostia/><ref>Evans, Sandra. "Wilson Says He Probably Will Not Run for Mayor". ''The Washington Post''. April 9, 1986. p. B1.</ref> Unemployed and living in [[Anacostia]], Gurley ran as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] candidate, challenging [[Marion Barry]]'s reelection.<ref name= anacostia/> Gurley said he was running for office so that a lifelong District resident would be in charge of the District's government.<ref name= anacostia/> Gurley advocated for improvements to the District's prison system and housing department, and he said that Mayor Barry's leadership was "decaying".<ref name= anacostia/>
The District of Columbia Office of Business and Economic Development opened a neighborhood revitalization office in Anacostia, in order to give low-interest loans to small businesses for upgrades to the business' outside appearance.<ref name= third>Jackson, Kirk. "Third Neighborhood Revitalization Office Opens". ''Washington Informer''. May 21, 1986. p. 7.</ref> Gurley described the office as "a solution in search of a problem".<ref name= third/> Gurley said that businesses in Anacostia needed "money" and "technical assistance" rather than an governmental agency that did little more than "filling office space".<ref name= third/>
During a scheduled debate among the mayoral candidates, Gurley called for the [[death penalty]] for [[drug addiction|drug addicts]] who contribute to [[drug overdose]]s of other people.<ref name= clash>Brisbane, Arthur S. "Barry, Challengers Clash on issues at Forum". ''The Washington Post''. July 24, 1986. p. C5.</ref> The audience loudly booed him for his statement.<ref name= clash/> Gurley later corrected himself, saying he meant to say he supported the death penalty for [[drug dealer]]s who contribute to drug overdoses.<ref name= clash/>
Gurley said that drug dealers should not be eligible for [[bail]] or [[parole]].<ref name= notasingle>Brisbane, Arthur S. "D.C. Mayoral Campaign Not a Single-Issue Race: Candidates Cite Drugs, Crime, Housing and Jobs". ''The Washington Post''. September 3, 1986. p. C7.</ref> Gurley said he would decrease the crime rate by increasing funding for job training.<ref name= notasingle/>
At a candidates forum in [[Neighborhoods in Washington, D.C.#Ward 8|Ward 8]], Gurley showed a [[slide show]] of [[urban decay|boarded-up house]]s, blaming Mayor Barry for their condition.<ref name= foes>Brisbane, Arthur S. "Foes Challenge Barry's Record On Housing and Rent Control". ''The Washington Post''. July 30, 1986. p. B7.</ref> At another campaign stop, Gurley said that vacant houses should be renovated more quickly and that new housing developments should have more homes available for low- and middle-income residents.<ref name= notasingle/>
Gurley repeated his campaign theme of "anybody but Barry".<ref name= accuse>Brisbane, Arthur S. "Challengers Accuse Barry of Mismanagement: Mayor Defends Record, Says He Has Decreased Crime, Improved Employment". ''The Washington Post''. August 20, 1986. p. C3.</ref> Gurley criticized Barry for sending [[Marion C. Barry|his son]] to a private school.<ref name= accuse/> Gurley noted that public schooling was suitable for [[President of the United States|President]] [[Jimmy Carter]]'s [[Amy Carter|daughter]] but not for Barry's son.<ref name= accuse/> Gurley suggested that Barry would increase funding for public schools if his own son were attending them.<ref name= accuse/> Gurley said he would voluntarily take a [[drug test]] and challenged Barry to do the same.<ref name= notasingle/>
Gurley said the most serious problem facing the District was that federal authorities had taken control of certain functions of the [[government of the District of Columbia]] due to mismanagement, resulting in what Gurley called "the loss of [[District of Columbia home rule|home rule]]".<ref name= vg1986>"District of Columbia Voters' Guide". ''The Washington Post''. September 4, 1986. p. VG2.</ref> Gurley said that the District had not improved at all during the previous four years, with the exception of [[downtown, Washington, D.C.|downtown]].<ref name= vg1986/>
At a meeting of the District of Columbia Ward 6 Democrats, the group decided to endorse Barry for reelection.<ref name= ward6dems>Brisbane, Arthur S. "Barry Wins Endorsement: Foes Decry 'Staged Event' in D.C. Ward 6". ''The Washington Post''. August 6, 1986. p. B7.</ref> In the [[straw vote]], Barry received 74 percent, candidate Mattie Taylor received 16 percent, and Gurley received 9 percent.<ref name= ward6dems/> Gurley's campaign chairman, Doug McLellan, called the event a "staged event" and accused Barry's campaign of packing the meeting with his supporters.<ref name= ward6dems/> The president of the group said the straw vote was legitimate because it was publicized widely and that Gurley lost the straw vote because his campaign did not have much visibility around the ward.<ref name= ward6dems/> At meeting of the Ward 4 Democrats, the results of the straw vote were 95 percent for Barry, 4 percent for Taylor, and 1 percent for Gurley.<ref name= accuse/>
Barry won the primary election with 71 percent of the vote.<ref>Brisbane, Arthur S. "Barry Gains Landslide In District: Clarke, Nathanson Win, Spaulding Loses In Voting for Council". ''The Washington Post''. September 10, 1986. p. A1.</ref><ref name= 1986p/> Taylor received 20 percent, Gurley received 6 percent, and 4 percent of voters [[write-in|wrote in]] another name.<ref name= 1986p/>
===1990 campaign for Mayor=== In February 1990, Gurley announced he would [[Washington, D.C. mayoral election, 1990|run for mayor]] again.<ref>York, Michael. "Barry Perjury Charge To Be Sought Today: Two Key Supporters Turn to Fauntroy". ''The Washington Post''. February 15, 1990. p. A1.</ref>
At a debate held in March, Gurley advocated for a publicly funded military school for youths in order to prevent drug use.<ref name= marchdebate>Melton, R. H. "Democratic Hopefuls Debate Without Barry". ''The Washington Post''. March 22, 1990. p. D1.</ref> In Gurley's words, the District should "grab these kids off the street from mothers who don't care" and enroll them at the military academy.<ref name= marchdebate/>
In May, Gurley was interviewed about his mayoral campaign on [[WHUT-TV|WHUT]]'s "Evening Exchange".<ref>Carmody, John. "The TV Column". ''The Washington Post''. May 15, 1990. p. C6.</ref>
In August, Gurley dropped out of the race in order to run for the Ward 6 seat on the [[Council of the District of Columbia]].<ref name= beat>Abramowitz, Michael. "Candidates Play Beat the Clock: D.C. Board of Elections Gets Crush of Petitions Near Deadline". July 6, 1990. p. D3.</ref>
===1990 campaign for Council, Ward 6=== At the time of Gurley's candidacy to represent Ward 6 on the Council of the District of Columbia,<ref name= beat/> Gurley was working as a financial accountant for the [[Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation]].<ref name= vg1990>"Voter's Guide: Ward 6". ''The Washington Post''. September 6, 1990. p. H5.</ref>
Gurley continued to support the establishment of a public military school for youth in the District. Gurley wanted police officers to walk the streets in order to stop individuals from [[loitering]].<ref name= vg1990/> Gurley wanted to make sure taxis would serve the neighborhood of Anacostia so that people doing neighborhood patrols could teach children instead.<ref name= vg1990/> Gurley wanted the District to use property confiscated in drug arrests to be used to fund drug education and prevention, additional pay for police officers, and youth-recreation projects.<ref name= vg1990/>
[[Harold Brazil]] won with 43 percent of the vote, unseating incumbent [[Nadine P. Winter]].<ref name= winter>Sanchez, Rene. "Winter Loses Ward 6 Seat: Wilson, Cropp Triumph". ''The Washington Post''. September 12, 1990. p. A21.</ref><ref name= 1990p/> Gurley received 3 percent of the vote.<ref name= 1990p/>
===2004 proposed ballot initiative=== In 2004, Gurley proposed a ballot initiative called "Mr. Bill Cosby’s Age 18 House Rule".<ref name= dontcall>Silverman, Elissa. "[http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/news/loose-lips/article/13029117/dont-call-it-a-comebackyet Don't Call It a Comeback...Yet]". ''Washington City Paper''. June 4, 2004.</ref>
If approved by voters, all [[child support|child-support payments]] would end when the reached became 18 years old, rather than 21 years old as District law stated.<ref name= dontcall/>
At the time, Gurley paid child support for two of his children, a 9-year-old daughter and a nearly 18-year-old son.<ref name= dontcall/>
Gurley explained the ballot initiative, saying that "black families still carry as their commandment, is once you reach 18, you're out the house."<ref name= dontcall/>
Gurley did not submit sufficient valid signatures to the District of Columbia Board of Elections, and the proposed ballot initiative did not appear on the ballot.
===2004 campaign for Democratic State Committee, Ward 4=== Gurley ran to represent Ward 4 on the [[District of Columbia Democratic State Committee]] in 2004.<ref>"[https://www.nist.gov/sites/default/files/documents/itl/vote/DC-85X14Speci-Sept2004.pdf September 14, 2004 - Primary Election Specimen Ballot]". ''District of Columbia Board of Elections and Ethics''. 2004.</ref>
Paul R. McKenzie won the seat with 42 percent of the vote.<ref name= 2004p>"[https://www.dcboee.org/pdf_files/14Sep2004_Certified_Summary_Report.pdf Certified Summary Report: September 14, 2004 Election]". ''District of Columbia Board of Elections and Ethics''. September 27, 2004.</ref> Gurley came in fourth place with 13 percent.<ref name= 2004p/>
===2010 campaign for Mayor=== Gurley ran for mayor in 2010.<ref name= where>DeBonis, Mike. "[https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/mike-debonis/wp/2012/11/07/where-did-calvin-h-gurley-find-57119-votes/ Where did Calvin H. Gurley find 57,119 votes?] ''The Washington Post''. November 7, 2012.</ref> Gurley did have enough valid signatures to appear on the ballot, so he decided to run as a [[write-in]] candidate instead.<ref name= where/>
[[Vincent C. Gray|Vincent Gray]] won the Democratic Party primary election for mayor with 54 percent of the vote.<ref name=2010p>"[https://web.archive.org/web/20110725221954/http://www.dcboee.org/election_info/election_results/results_2010.asp?prev=0&electionid=4&result_type=3 Election Results, Primary Election 2010, DC Mayor]". ''District of Columbia Board of Elections''. September 14, 2010. Retrieved on August 27, 2011. Archived from [http://www.dcboee.org/election_info/election_results/results_2010.asp?prev=0&electionid=4&result_type=3 the original] on July 25, 2011.</ref> [[Write-in]] candidates received 0.19 percent of the vote; some of these were for Gurley.<ref name=2010p/><ref name= where/>
===2011 campaign for Council, At-large=== ====Vote by Democratic State Committee==== When [[at-large]] Council member [[Kwame R. Brown]] was sworn into office as [[chairman|chair]] of the [[Council of the District of Columbia]] in 2011, the [[District of Columbia Democratic State Committee]] announced an election by its members to replace Brown as interim at-large member of the Council until a [[special election]] could occur.<ref name=pick>Craig, Tim; DeBonis, Mike. "[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/04/AR2011010404963.html D.C. Democrats to pick interim at-large council member]". ''The Washington Post''. January 4, 2011.</ref> Gurley, [[Sekou Biddle]], former Council member [[Vincent Orange]], and several others filed to run.<ref>Wright, James. "[http://www.washingtoninformer.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5182:eight-file-with-democrats-to-replace-kwame-brown&catid=50:local&Itemid=113 Eight File with Democrats to Replace Kwame Brown]". ''Washington Informer''. December 15, 2010.</ref>
At a debate before the District of Columbia Democratic State Committee, Gurley said that when companies hire people who live outside the District, it is like "[[genocide]]".<ref>Orvetti, P.J. "[http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/politics/DMV-Daily-Lanier-Stays-112055934.html DMV Daily: Lanier Stays]". ''[[WRC-TV|WRC]]''. December 17, 2010.</ref>
Kwame Brown endorsed Biddle for the position, as did Council members [[Harry Thomas Jr.]], [[Mary Cheh]], [[Muriel Bowser]], [[Yvette Alexander]], and [[Marion Barry]].<ref name=pick/> District mayor [[Vincent C. Gray|Vincent Gray]] said he supported Brown's endorsement of Biddle.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mayor stops just short of endorsing Sekou Biddle |first=Nikita R |last=Stewart |work=The Washington Post |date=January 6, 2011 |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/dc/2011/01/mayor_vincent_gray_stops_just.html }}</ref>
On January 6, 2011, the District of Columbia Democratic State Committee voted to select Biddle as the interim at-large member of the Council.<ref name=secretly>Craig, Tim. "[http://voices.washingtonpost.com/dc/2011/01/dc_democrats_secretly_select_b.html D.C. Democrats secretly select Biddle]". ''The Washington Post''. January 7, 2011.</ref> Vote tallies were not publicly reported.<ref name= secretly/>
====Special election==== After the District of Columbia Democratic State Committee voted to select Sekou Biddle as the interim at-large member of the Council, a [[special election]] was announced, to be held on April 26, 2011.<ref name = 11enter>Craig, Tim. "11 enter at-large D.C. Council race". ''The Washington Post''. February 18, 2011. p. B5.</ref>
Gurley, [[Sekou Biddle]], [[Vincent Orange]], [[Patrick Mara]], and several others filed to run.<ref name = 11enter/><ref>"Johnson, Reginald. "You want to be a council member too?" ''Washington Examiner''. February 19, 2011.</ref>
Gurley did not appear on the ballot because he did not submit enough valid signatures to the [[District of Columbia Board of Elections]].<ref>Suderman, Alan. "[http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/news/loose-lips/blog/13132352/4605 Loose Lips Daily: Kwame Keep Digging Edition]". ''Washington City Paper''. February 22, 2011.</ref>
===2012 campaign for Council, Ward 4=== Gurley ran for the Council again in 2012, this time to represent [[Neighborhoods in Washington, D.C.#Ward 4|Ward 4]].<ref>Suderman, Alan. "[http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/news/loose-lips/blog/13133062/challengers-having-a-hard-time-knocking-bowser Challengers Having A Hard Time Knocking Bowser]". ''Washington City Paper''. March 14, 2012.</ref>
In the Democratic Party primary election held in January 2012, [[Muriel Bowser]] won with 66 percent of the vote.<ref name= 2012p/> Gurley came in sixth place with 2 percent of the vote.<ref name= 2012p/>
===2012 campaign for Council, Chair=== In June 2012, [[Kwame R. Brown|Kwame Brown]] resigned from the position of [[Chairman|Chair]] of the Council.<ref name=resigns>Wilber, Del Quentin; Craig, Tim. "[https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/crime/2012/06/06/gJQAUXJqIV_story.html D.C. Council Chairman Kwame Brown resigns after he is charged with bank fraud]". ''The Washington Post''. June 6, 2012.</ref>
Gurley filed to run a [[special election]] for the position of Council Chair that was held in November 2012.<ref>"[http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/news/article/13043215/duly-voted-washington-city-papers-endorsements Duly Voted]". ''Washington City Paper''. October 26, 2012.</ref> [[Phil Mendelson]] and Gurley were the only two candidates on the ballot.<ref>"DC voters ready to cast ballots on Election Day". ''Washington Examiner''. November 6, 2012.</ref>
Gurley said that the District did a good job by warning the public about the dangers of [[Hurricane Sandy]].<ref name= sandy>"Hurricane Sandy DC Voter Guide 2012: Calvin Gurley". ''Washington Examiner''. October 31, 2012.</ref> Gurley said that the District should open a Disaster Emergency Management Assistance Office that would distribute power generators and subsidize hotel stays during emergency storms.<ref name= sandy/> Gurley said he would ask [[Potomac Electric Power Company|PEPCO]] to fund much of the office's cost.<ref name= sandy/>
Gurley reported a total of $650 of contributions to his campaign.<ref name= october>Sommer, Will. "[http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/news/loose-lips/blog/13134083/october-campaign-reports-everything-else October Campaign Reports: Everything Else]". ''Washington City Paper''. October 14, 2013.</ref> Gurley was the only donor.<ref name= october/>
Mendelson won the special election with 71 percent of the vote.<ref name= 2012s/><ref>Phipps-Evans, Michelle. "The Council Shuffle Begins". ''Washington Informer''. November 15, 2012. p. 5.</ref> Gurley received 28 percent of the vote.<ref name= 2012s/>
When asked by ''The Washington Post'' what Gurley did to receive 28 percent of the vote, Gurley said, "I just campaigned hard. It was just traditional grassroots campaigning. Hand to hand, face to face."<ref>Suderman, Alan. "[http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/news/loose-lips/blog/13133527/calvin-gurley-i-just-campaigned-hard Calvin Gurley: 'I Just Campaigned Hard']". ''Washington City Paper''. November 8, 2012.</ref>
===2014 campaign for Council, Chair=== Gurley filed to run again for Chair of the Council in the 2014 election.<ref>Sommer, Will. "[http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/news/loose-lips/blog/13134208/december-finance-reports-everyone-else December Finance Reports: Everyone Else]". ''Washington City Paper''. December 12, 2013.</ref><ref>Sommer, Will. "[http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/news/loose-lips/blog/13134231/thought-2013-was-a-wild-year-for-d-c-politics-just-wait Thought 2013 Was a Wild Year for D.C. Politics? Just Wait]". ''Washington City Paper''. December 30, 2013.</ref> Gurley and Mendelson were the only candidates on the ballot in the Democratic Party primary election.<ref>"[http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/news/city-desk/blog/13068450/who-to-vote-for-and-who-not-to-vote-for-in-d-c-s-2014-democratic-primary Who to Vote for (and Who Not to Vote for) in D.C.'s 2014 Democratic Primary]". ''Washington City Paper''. March 26, 2014.</ref><ref>Sommer, Will. "[http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/news/loose-lips/blog/13134587/fuzz-fuss-with-mendelson-but-to-what-endFuzz Fuss With Mendelson—But to What End?]" ''Washington City Paper''. May 7, 2014.</ref>
Gurley and other candidates were invited to speak at a meeting of the Gertrude Stein Democratic Club, the largest [[LGBT]] political organization in the District.<ref name= unable>Chibbaro Jr., Lou. "[http://www.washingtonblade.com/2014/02/27/stein-club-unable-endorse-3-council-races/ Stein Club unable to endorse in 3 Council races]". ''Washington Blade''. February 27, 2014.</ref> Gurley did not address any issues specific to LGBT individuals.<ref name= unable/> Instead, Gurley talked about corruption and waste in the District.<ref name= unable/> The group rated Gurley a zero out of a possible ten points because the group had no knowledge of Gurley's view on issues that were important to LGBT individuals.<ref name= unable/>
The [[Fraternal Order of Police|Fraternal Order of Police, Metropolitan Police Department Labor Committee]] said that Mendelson did not do enough to prevent the number of anti-LGBT hate crimes from nearly doubling between 2009 and 2011.<ref name= attack>Chibbaro Jr., Lou. "[http://www.washingtonblade.com/2014/03/31/attack-ad-blames-mendelson-rise-hate-crimes/ Attack ad blames Mendelson for rise in hate crimes]". ''Washington Blade''. March 31, 2014.</ref> The group asked District residents to "vote no on Phil Mendelson", but it did not actually endorse Gurley.<ref name= attack/>
Mendelson won the election with 81 percent of the vote.<ref>Sommer, Will. "[http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/news/loose-lips/blog/13134672/three-more-candidates-enter-at-large-race Three More Candidates Enter At-Large Race]". ''Washington City Paper''. June 16, 2014.</ref><ref name= 2014p/> Gurley received 18 percent of the vote.<ref name= 2014p/>
===2014 campaign for Council, At-large=== When [[independent (politician)|independent]] Council Member [[David Catania]] decided to run for [[mayor of the District of Columbia|mayor]] rather than reelection in 2014,<ref name= consider>DeBonis, Mike. "[http://search.proquest.com/docview/1514127058/ Democrats consider independent runs for council]". ''The Washington Post''. April 10, 2014. p. B2.</ref> Gurley changed his voter registration to [[independent (politician)|unaffiliated]] and filed to run for an [[at-large]] seat on the Council.<ref>Sommer, Will. "[http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/news/loose-lips/blog/13134672/three-more-candidates-enter-at-large-raceThree More Candidates Enter At-Large Race]". ''Washington City Paper''. June 16, 2014.</ref>
Gurley said the District government should create and maintain its public housing.<ref name= meet/> He said that the mayor should not have full control of the public school system.<ref name= meet/> Gurley said that [[United States Congress|Congress]] was responsible for the fact that 70 percent of employees working in the District live outside of the District.<ref name= meet/> If elected, he said he would introduce a bill to create a committee on housing and job development.<ref name= meet/>
The District of Columbia Gay and Lesbian Activists Alliance asked each candidate to answer 12 questions about the group's issues.<ref name= top>Sommer, Will. "[http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/news/loose-lips/blog/13134859/catania-bowser-score-top-ratings-from-gay-group Catania, Bowser Score Top Ratings From Gay Group]". ''Washington City Paper''. September 17, 2014.</ref> The Gay and Lesbian Activists Alliance graded Gurley a 2 out of a possible 10 points.<ref name= top/> Gay and Lesbian Activists Alliance described Gurley's responses as "confused rants".<ref name= top/>
Gurley's campaign reported $2,087 of contributions, including $1,812 from Gurley himself.<ref name= looming/>
Gurley came in twelfth place with one percent of the total vote.<ref name=2014g/>
===2016 campaign for Council, Ward 4=== Gurley ran as a Democrat in the election to represent [[Neighborhoods in Washington, D.C.#Ward 4|Ward 4]] on the Council in 2016.<ref name= behold>Sommer, Will. "[http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/news/loose-lips/blog/13135850/behold-the-2016-primary-ballot-orders Behold" The 2016 Primary Ballot Orders]". ''Washington City Paper''. April 22, 2016.</ref><ref>Sommer, Will. "[http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/news/loose-lips/blog/20683413/leon-andrews-is-spending-tens-of-thousands-of-his-own-dollars-to-oust-brandon-todd-in-ward-4 Leon Andrews Is Spending Tens of Thousands of His Own Dollars To Oust Brandon Todd in Ward 4]". ''Washington City Paper''. May 5, 2016.</ref> [[Brandon Todd (politician)|Brandon Todd]] ran for reelection.<ref name= fortunes>McDermott, Ryan M. "Muriel Bowser's fortunes with D.C. council hinge on elections". ''The Washington Times''. June 13, 2016.</ref> [[Leon Andrews]] and Ron Austin were also candidates.<ref name= fortunes/>
Gurley said that [[Metropolitan Police Department of the District of Columbia|Metropolitan Police]] [[Cathy Lanier|Chief Cathy Lanier]] was "dismantling" of the department's LGBT Liaison Unit by not replacing officers who left the unit to take other assignments.<ref name= clintonwins>Chibbaro Jr., Lou. "[http://www.washingtonblade.com/2016/04/27/clinton-wins-stein-club-endorsement/ Clinton wins Stein Club endorsement]". ''Washington Blade''. April 27, 2016.</ref> Gurley blamed Todd for not addressing the issue.<ref name= clintonwins/>
Gurley and other candidates completed a questionnaire by the Gay and Lesbian Activists Alliance.<ref name= glaa2016>Chibbaro Jr., Lou. "[http://www.washingtonblade.com/2016/06/08/gay-candidate-2nd-in-fundraising-for-d-c-council-race/ Gay candidate 2nd in fundraising for D.C. Council race]". ''Washington Blade''. June 8, 2016.</ref> The Gay and Lesbian Activists Alliance rated Gurley's responses with a score of 3.5 out of 10 points.<ref name= glaa2016/>
Todd was reelected to the Council, receiving 49 percent of the vote.<ref name= 2016p2>Chibbaro Jr., Lou. "[http://www.washingtonblade.com/2016/06/15/clinton-gray-win-big-in-d-c-primary/ Clinton, Gray win big in D.C. primary]". ''Washington Blade''. June 15, 2016.</ref> Gurley came in fourth place with 3 percent of the vote.<ref name= 2016p2/>
===2018 campaign for Council, Chair=== Gurley is running for Chair of the Council in 2018.<ref name= spar>Nirappil, Fenit (February 8, 2018). "Mendelson, Lazere spar for first time at forum". ''The Washington Post''. p. B4.</ref> Gurley is running against incumbent Phil Mendelson.<ref name= spar/> [[Ed Lazere]], executive director of the D.C. Fiscal Policy Institute, is also running for Chair of the Council.<ref name= spar/>
==Activism== Gurley served as the [[President (corporation)|president]] of the [[Fairlawn (Washington, D.C.)|Fairlawn Civic Association]] between 1987 and 1988, where he helped establish neighborhood patrols.<ref name= 1990vg>"Ward 6". ''The Washington Post''. September 6, 1990. p. H5.</ref>
Gurley served as the [[executive director]] of Mothers of Lost Sons in 1988.<ref name= mothers>Sanchez, Carlos. "National Guard Aid Urged in Drug War". ''The Washington Post''. March 31, 1988. p. C4.</ref> The group was primarily made of people whose relatives were recently murdered.<ref name= mothers/> The group wanted a [[List of United States military schools and academies|federally sponsored military academy]] to be established in the District as an alternative to [[Youth detention center#District of Columbia|juvenile detention center]]s.<ref name= mothers/>

'''Carbonatation''' is a [[chemical reaction]] in which [[calcium hydroxide]] reacts with [[carbon dioxide]] and forms insoluble [[calcium carbonate]]:
:Ca(OH)<sub>2</sub> + CO<sub>2</sub> → CaCO<sub>3</sub> + H<sub>2</sub>O
The process of forming a carbonate is sometimes referred to as "[[carbonation]]", although this term usually refers to the process of dissolving carbon dioxide in water.
==Concrete== [[File:Betonrot Hippodroom.JPG|thumb|right|300px|Carbonatation induced rebar corrosion]] Carbonatation is a slow process that occurs in [[concrete]] where [[Lime (material)|lime]] ([[Calcium oxide|CaO]], or [[Calcium hydroxide|Ca(OH)<sub>2</sub>]]<sub>([[Aqueous solution|au]])</sub>) in the [[cement]] reacts with [[carbon dioxide]] (CO<sub>2</sub>) from the [[air]] and forms calcium carbonate.
The water in the pores of Portland cement concrete is normally [[alkaline]] with a [[pH]] in the range of 12.5 to 13.5. This highly alkaline environment is one in which the steel [[rebar]] is passivated and is protected from corrosion. According to the [[Pourbaix diagram]] for iron, the metal is passive when the pH is above 9.5.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.corrosion-doctors.org/Thermo/ironE-pH.htm |title=Pourbaix diagram of iron |publisher=Corrosion-doctors.org |date= |accessdate=2009-10-14}}</ref>
The carbon dioxide in the air reacts with the [[alkali]] in the cement and makes the pore water more acidic, thus lowering the pH. Carbon dioxide will start to carbonatate the cement in the concrete from the moment the object is made. This carbonatation process will start at the surface, then slowly move deeper and deeper into the concrete. The rate of carbonatation is dependent on the relative humidity of the concrete - a 50% relative humidity being optimal. If the object is cracked, the carbon dioxide in the air will be better able to penetrate into the concrete.
Eventually this may lead to corrosion of the rebar and structural damage or failure.
==Sugar refining== The carbonatation process is used in the production of [[sugar]] from [[sugar beet]]s. It involves the introduction of [[limewater]] (milk of lime - [[calcium hydroxide]] [[Suspension (chemistry)|suspension]]) and carbon dioxide enriched gas into the "raw juice" (the sugar rich liquid prepared from the diffusion stage of the process) to form calcium carbonate and precipitate impurities that are then removed. The whole process takes place in "carbonatation tanks" and processing time varies from 20 minutes to an hour.
Carbonatation involves the following effects: * The increase in [[alkalinity]] [[coagulation|coagulates]] [[protein]]s in the juice. * Calcium carbonate absorbs colourants * Alkalinity destroys some [[monosaccharide]] sugars, mostly [[glucose]] and [[fructose]]
The target is a large particle that naturally settles rapidly to leave a clear juice. The juice at the end is approximately 15 [[Brix|°Bx]] and 90% [[sucrose]]. The [[pH]] of the thin juice produced is a balance between removing as much [[calcium]] from the solution and the expected pH drop across later processing. If the juice goes [[acid]]ic in the [[crystallization|crystallisation]] stages then sucrose rapidly breaks down to [[glucose]] and [[fructose]]; not only do glucose and fructose affect crystallisation but they are ''[[molasses|molassagenic]]'' taking equivalent amounts of sucrose on to the molasses stage.
The carbon dioxide gas bubbled through the mixture forms calcium carbonate. The non-sugar solids are incorporated into the calcium carbonate particles and removed by natural (or assisted) [[sedimentation]] in tanks.
There are several systems of carbonatation, named from the companies that first developed them. They differ in how the lime is introduced, the temperature and duration of each stage, and the separation of the solids from the liquid. * [[John V. N. Dorr|Dorr]] (also [[Dorr-Oliver]]) - a continuous process using two tanks with recycling ("1st carbonatation") to build up particle size for natural [[flocculation]]. The recycling ratio is about 7:1. The particles are separated under gravity in a thickening stage in a vessel called a [[clarifier]]. The clear juice is then gassed further in another tank ("2nd carbonatation") and filtered. The concentrated mud (underflow) from the clarifier is filtered and/or pressed to recover more liquid. The Dorr process is low in maintenance and man-power but susceptible to filtration problems when frost damaged beets are processed. It is favoured in the UK and the USA. * DDS (''Det Danske Sukkerfabrik'' - "The Danish Sugarfactory") -- multistage process involving pre-liming where the [[pH]] of the juice is gradually increased to start precipitation of proteins, followed by addition of further lime and CO<sub>2</sub> gas. The particles are removed at each stage by filtration. * RT (''Raffinerie Tirlemontoise'' - "[[Sugar refinery of Tienen]]") - another multistage process with a pre-liming stage. Particles also removed by filtration.
Both DDS and RT processes are favoured by [[Europe]]an factories. The carbonatation system is generally matched to the [[Sugar beet#Diffusion|diffusion scheme]]; juice from RT diffusers being processed by the RT carbonatation.
The clear juice from carbonatation is generally known as "thin juice". it may undergo pH adjustment with [[soda ash]] and addition of [[sulfur]] ("sulfitation") prior to the next stage which is concentration by multiple effect evaporation.
==Water softening== The carbonatation reaction takes place during [[lime softening]] (Clark's process) in [[water softening]].
==See also== *[[Concrete cancer]] *[[Phosphotation]] — a similar process used in [[Sugarcane#Refining|sugarcane processing]].

{{Use British English|date=July 2018}} In the United Kingdom, a '''competent person''' is designated by a company to ensure that the company's [[Health-and-safety|health and safety]] responsibilities are being met.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.hse.gov.uk/competence/what-is-competence.htm|title=What is Competence? - Competence in health and safety|website=www.hse.gov.uk|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref> This may be a legal obligation required of the company, to ensure that the business understands, and can act on, the health and safety risks that might occur during their particular type of work.<ref name=":0" />
Recognition of competence is defined as requiring "sufficient training and experience or knowledge and other qualities" to be able to effectively oversee health and safety in the business,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/1999/3242/regulation/7/made|title=The Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999|website=www.legislation.gov.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref> although specialised industries may have additional, more specific requirements.<ref name=":0" />
For building trades, there are various Competent Person Schemes<ref>Gov.uk https://www.gov.uk/guidance/competent-person-scheme-current-schemes-and-how-schemes-are-authorised#current-schemes</ref> including: *Fensa (for windows) *HETAS (for biomass and solid fuel) *[[NICEIC]] (for electrical installations)

The '''Credit Managers' Index''' '''(CMI)''' is a monthly economic indicator of financial activity reflecting credit managers' responses to levels of favorable and unfavorable factors. The measure has been sourced in stories from publications such as the ''Wall Street Journal'', ''CFO'' and ''Bloomberg''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ww2.cfo.com/credit/2015/09/credit-managers-index-continues-decline/|title=Credit Managers' Index Continues to Decline -|last=Kuehner-Hebert|first=Katie|date=2015-09-30|language=en-US|access-date=2016-06-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2012-11-01/economy-looking-up-ahead-of-big-jobs-number|title=Economy Looking Up Ahead of Big Jobs Number|last=Coy|first=Peter|website=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2016-06-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/economics/2007/10/01/woes-dont-extend-to-credit-managers/|title=Woes Don’t Extend to Credit Managers|last=WSJ|access-date=2016-06-30}}</ref>
Tracked since February 2002, the CMI is produced by the [[National Association of Credit Management]] (NACM)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nacm.org/cmi.html|title=Credit Managers' Index (CMI)|website=nacm.org|access-date=2016-06-30}}</ref> and is currently conducted by Armada Corporate Intelligence's Chris Kuehl, who also serves as NACM's economic advisor. The CMI is compiled through a voluntary poll of credit and finance professionals in the service and manufacturing sectors. The CMI results generally are released on the last business day of each month.<ref>http://web.nacm.org/CMI/PDF/CMIcurrent.pdf</ref>
A CMI number of more than 50 indicates an economy in expansion; less than 50 indicates contraction.
Unlike many economic indexes, the CMI resisted the month-to-month swings during the most recent{{when?|date=October 2017}} economic downturn. The index accurately signaled that the economic plunge was stabilizing and beginning to recover from the recession.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nacmnc.org/news/news.asp?id=271241|title=Simple Act, Huge Impact - NACM North Central|website=www.nacmnc.org|access-date=2017-11-28}}</ref>
The Chartered Institute of Credit Management (CICM) in the UK produces a similar Index<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cicm.com/credit-management-index/|title=CICM UK Credit Management Index - Chartered Institute of Credit Management|language=en-US|access-date=2016-06-30}}</ref> on a quarterly basis reflecting its members' responses to questions about the same factors and it uses the same methodology.
==Methodology== The index is based on survey responses of approximately 1,000 trade credit managers in the second half of each month. There is typically an approximately equal representation between the manufacturing and service sectors. Respondents from throughout the United States are asked to comment on whether they are seeing improvement, deterioration, or no change for various favorable and unfavorable factors.
The computation of seasonality is based on the formula used by the U.S. Census Bureau and most of the federal government's statistical gathering apparatus. This is designed to streamline comparisons between the CMI diffusion index and comparable indices.

'''Eugene Lawrence "Gene" Case''' (December 6, 1937 – September 9, 2010) was an American [[advertising]] executive who developed campaigns for Mennen [[Skin Bracer]] and [[Tums]], and developed ads for political campaigns for [[Lyndon B. Johnson]]'s [[United States presidential election, 1964|1964 presidential election]] campaign, as well as for [[Nelson Rockefeller]] and [[Robert F. Wagner]]. Case was a founder of the firm Jordan McGrath Case & Partners.
Case was born on December 6, 1937, in [[Knoxville, Tennessee]], where his father worked for the [[Tennessee Valley Authority]]. The success his father had in the [[New Deal]] helped shape Case's liberal philosophy, saying "''I saw government lift [my home] region out of Appalachian-style poverty".<ref>Stone, Todd. [http://adage.com/article?article_id=145864 "Gene Case, 72, Dies of Heart Attack"], ''[[Advertising Age]]'', September 13, 2010. Accessed September 14, 2010.</ref>'' He earned his undergraduate degree from [[Cornell University]], where he majored in architecture and was a member of the [[Quill and Dagger]] society. He entered the advertising field in 1961, when he took a position as a copywriter at the [[J. Walter Thompson]] agency.<ref name=NYTObit>Weber, Bruce. [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/14/business/media/14case.html "Gene Case, Who Marketed After-Shave and Politicians, Dies at 72"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', September 13, 2010. Accessed September 14, 2010.</ref>
While with [[DDB Worldwide|Doyle Dane Bernbach]], Case worked with [[Tony Schwartz (sound archivist)|Tony Schwartz]] as part of the team that developed the "[[Daisy (advertisement)|Daisy ad]]" for Johnson's 1964 campaign.<ref>Mann, Robert. [https://books.google.com/books?id=7PlUY5YSp_sC&pg=PA57 ''Daisy Petals and Mushroom Clouds: LBJ, Barry Goldwater, and the Ad that Changed American Politics''], p. 57, [[Louisiana State University Press]], 2011. {{ISBN|080714293X}}. Accessed December 4, 2014.</ref> Depicting a girl counting petals plucked from a daisy, the voiceover changes to a countdown that ends with the mushroom cloud of a nuclear explosion. Case wrote the copy for another Johnson ad in which a man who says he had always been a Republican speaks to the camera for four minutes about his fear of [[Barry Goldwater]] being elected. Case worked for [[Nelson Rockefeller]]'s successful bid for a third term as [[Governor of New York]] in the [[New York state election, 1966|1966 elections]] where he produced ads on pollution control, and he later worked on [[New York City]] mayoral bids by [[Robert F. Wagner]] and [[Bella Abzug]].<ref name=NYTObit/>
Case founded Jordan McGrath Case & Partners with [[Helmut Krone]] in 1969, operating out of a suite at the [[Plaza Hotel]], with Pat McGrath joining shortly thereafter. A $500,000 campaign they nabbed that year for [[Angostura bitters]] was the agency's first commercial account.<ref>Staff. [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-58826834.html "30 YEARS OF JORDAN, MCGRATH"], ''[[Advertising Age]]'', May 24, 1999. Accessed September 14, 2010.</ref> There he developed the "Thanks. I needed that." campaign for Mennen's Skin Bracer aftershave and the ''[[Dragnet (series)|Dragnet]]''-inspired "tum-ta-tum-tum" for [[Tums]] antacid. At its peak in the 1990s the firm had 350 employees and $500 million in annual billings. He and his partners sold Jordan McGrath to the [[France|French]] advertising firm [[Havas]] in 1999.<ref name=NYT1999/>
Case established the advocacy ad group Avenging Angels in 2002, creating ads for liberal causes such as those that supported a ban on assault weapons, opposed the war in Iraq, sought to stem nuclear proliferation and for the [[Hudson River]] advocacy group [[Riverkeeper]]. He told ''[[The New York Times]]'' that he was glad that he had made the shift back to issue advertising, saying "I've never been so productive, so happy — and so poor."<ref name=NYTObit/> Anti-Iraq War ads that Case had developed featuring [[Janeane Garofalo]] and [[Susan Sarandon]] in February 2003 were rejected by the major U.S. broadcast networks which said that they don't accept advocacy ads.<ref name=NYT1999>Lauro, Patricia Winters. [https://www.nytimes.com/2003/02/16/business/private-sector-aiming-at-hearts-not-wallets.html "Private Sector; Aiming at Hearts, Not Wallets"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', February 16, 2003. Accessed September 14, 2010.</ref>
Case died in [[Manhattan]] at age 72 on September 9, 2010, due to a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]]. He was survived by his third wife and their daughter, a daughter and two sons from his first marriage, a son from his second marriage and nine grandchildren.
